Url.Title: Welcome to the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard
Url.Abstract: Welcome to the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard Concepts: "Why You Use the Administration Dashboard" on page 1

Url.Title: Why You Use the Administration Dashboard
Url.Abstract: Why You Use the Administration Dashboard You can use the Administration Dashboard as a simplified means of creating and managing HP Cloud OS resources, topology designs, and deployment profiles.

Url.Title: Administration Dashboard Look and Feel
Url.Abstract: Administration Dashboard Look and Feel Concepts: Concepts The Administration Dashboard provides customized views by role. You see only the tabs and panels you need to do your job.

Url.Title: Administration Dashboard Tabs
Url.Abstract: Administration Dashboard Tabs Settings Tab Every HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard user can see the Settings tab.

Url.Title: Administration Dashboard Roles
Url.Abstract: Administration Dashboard Roles Roles define the type of access a user is granted within the cloud. Cloud Level Roles

Url.Title: Prerequisites to Accessing the Administration Dashboard
Url.Abstract: Prerequisites to Accessing the Administration Dashboard Administration Dashboard Before you can access the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard, someone in your organization must use the HP Cloud OS Operational Dashboard to install, set up, configure, and stand up a cloud environment. Use Operational Dashboard to set up and install an Admin node, create a cloud, define compute regions, and apply updates and extensions to your cloud. See HP Cloud OS Operational Dashboard Help.

Url.Title: How to Log in to the Administration Dashboard
Url.Abstract: How to Log in to the Administration Dashboard Administration Dashboard IMPORTANT: Use Google Chrome or Mozilla Firefox to access the Administration Dashboard.

Url.Title: Getting Started with the Administration Dashboard
Url.Abstract: Getting Started with the Administration Dashboard Concepts: Concepts When you start the Administration Dashboard for the first time, it includes one user (the Admin user), and one project (the AdminProject). To validate that the dashboard works, and to get started using it, users must work through a series of tasks.

Url.Title: Before You Begin with the Administration Dashboard Help
Url.Abstract: Before You Begin with the Administration Dashboard Help Before you begin with the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard Help, take a few minutes to understand how the help content is organized. You can find information in this order:

Url.Title: Getting Started for the Admin User
Url.Abstract: Getting Started for the Admin User Concepts: Concepts The Admin user creates projects and creates users for projects. An Admin user can view domains and services, and delete protected images.

Url.Title: Getting Started for Cloud Administrators
Url.Abstract: Getting Started for Cloud Administrators All administrator rights associated with the cloud and all HP Cloud OS services, including the ability to make resources available to users.

Url.Title: Getting Started for Cloud Architects
Url.Abstract: Getting Started for Cloud Architects Concepts: : Cloud architects create images,topology designs, and deployment profiles.

Url.Title: Getting Started for Project Administrators
Url.Abstract: Getting Started for Project Administrators Concepts: Concepts Project administrators have rights to modify and delete project resources and content.

Url.Title: Getting Started for Project Users
Url.Abstract: Getting Started for Project Users Concepts: Concepts Project users own only the content and resources they create. Project users can modify or delete the content and resources they own. Project users' main goal when using the dashboard is to provision topologies.

Url.Title: Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role
Url.Abstract: Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role The following topics describe HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard tasks for each dashboard role.

Url.Title: Admin User Tasks
Url.Abstract: Admin User Tasks Concepts: Concepts The Admin user creates projects and creates users for projects. An Admin user can view domains and services, and delete protected images. As a best practice, the Admin user performs the tasks below and works on the AdminProject.

Url.Title: How to Change Site Settings
Url.Abstract: How to Change Site Settings All Administration Dashboard users can access settings for User, Password, About, and Help.

Url.Title: Cloud Administrator Tasks
Url.Abstract: Cloud Administrator Tasks Concepts: Concepts After your organization works through Getting Started, cloud administrators can focus on day-to-day cloud administrator tasks. As a best practice, cloud administrators concentrate on the Cloud and Region tabs.

Url.Title: Cloud Architect Tasks
Url.Abstract: Cloud Architect Tasks Concepts: Concepts After your organization works through Getting Started, cloud architects can focus on day-to-day cloud architect tasks. As a best practice, cloud architects are mostly concerned with creating deployment profiles, topology designs, and load balancers, although they have rights to work with all the tasks listed below.

Url.Title: Load Balancers
Url.Abstract: Load Balancers Concepts: Concepts Tasks: Tasks "How to Create a Standalone Load Balancer" on page 1

Url.Title: How to Create a Standalone Load Balancer
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Standalone Load Balancer You can create a standalone (referenced instance) load balancer and use it to provide load balancing features for one or more provisioned topologies. Create the load balancer and reference it in your deployment profile.

Url.Title: Project Administrator Tasks
Url.Abstract: Project Administrator Tasks Concepts: Concepts After your organization works through Getting Started, project administrators can focus on their day-to-day tasks - monitoring and maintaining project resources and content. Project administrators have all the rights of project users, plus rights to modify or delete project resources and content.

Url.Title: Project User Tasks
Url.Abstract: Project User Tasks Concepts: Concepts After your organization works through Getting Started, project users can focus on day-to-day project tasks. They create topology designs and deployment profiles, and work with all the panels on the Project tab. Project users' main goal when using the dashboard is to provision topologies.

Url.Title: Administration Dashboard Tasks by Tab
Url.Abstract: Administration Dashboard Tasks by Tab Delete this text and replace it with your own content.

Url.Title: Cloud Tab Tasks
Url.Abstract: Cloud Tab Tasks The Cloud tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to access information on a cloud-wide basis.

Url.Title: How to See All Services
Url.Abstract: How to See All Services The Services window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a read-only list of services that are registered in the cloud.

Url.Title: How to See All Domains
Url.Abstract: How to See All Domains The Domains window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of domains in the cloud. (Currently, the cloud contains one domain.)

Url.Title: How to Access All Projects
Url.Abstract: How to Access All Projects Concepts: Concepts The Project window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of all projects in the cloud and to work with those projects. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Create a Project
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Project To learn whether you have permission to create a project on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to See a Project's Usage
Url.Abstract: How to See a Project's Usage To learn whether you have permission to see a project's usage on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Add or Remove a Project User
Url.Abstract: How to Add or Remove a Project User To learn whether you have permission to add or remove a project user on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Change a Project's Compute or Storage Limits
Url.Abstract: How to Change a Project's Compute or Storage Limits You can change your default compute and storage limits to more closely reflect your capacity. For example, if your compute region is hosted on a very large system, you can offer users more than the default capacity. If your compute region is hosted on a VM, you can restrict capacity.

Url.Title: How to Edit a Project Name or Description
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Project Name or Description To edit a project: Click Cloud > Projects to open the Projects window.

Url.Title: How to Delete or Restore a Project
Url.Abstract: How to Delete or Restore a Project When you delete a project, it is marked for deletion by adding a tilde (~) prefix to its name.

Url.Title: How to Access All Users
Url.Abstract: How to Access All Users Concepts: Concepts The Users window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of all users in the cloud and to work with those users. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Create a User
Url.Abstract: How to Create a User To learn whether you have permission to create a user on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Edit a User
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a User To learn whether you have permission to edit a user on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Delete, Disable, or Enable a User
Url.Abstract: How to Delete, Disable, or Enable a User To learn whether you have permission to perform the following tasks on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Access All Roles
Url.Abstract: How to Access All Roles Concepts: Concepts The Roles window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of all roles in the cloud and to work with those roles. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Create a Role
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Role Cloud administrators and the Admin user can create a new role on the Cloud tab. To create a role:

Url.Title: How to Edit a Role
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Role Cloud administrators and the Admin user can edit a role to change the name that is associated with the role. The role maintains the privileges that were previously assigned to it, but with a different name.

Url.Title: How to Delete a Role
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Role Cloud administrators and the Admin user can delete a role. When you delete a role, it is removed throughout the Administration Dashboard.

Url.Title: How to Access All Images
Url.Abstract: How to Access All Images Concepts: Concepts The Images window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of all images in the cloud and to work with those images. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Create an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Create an Image To learn whether you have permission to create an image on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Launch an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Launch an Image To learn whether you have permission to launch an image on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Edit an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Edit an Image To learn whether you have permission to edit an image on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Delete an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Delete an Image To learn whether you have permission to delete an image or protected image on the Cloud tab, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: Region Tab Tasks
Url.Abstract: Region Tab Tasks The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to work with region services and content. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to See an Overview of Usage
Url.Abstract: How to See an Overview of Usage The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a usage summary. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to See Instances
Url.Abstract: How to See Instances Concepts: Concepts Instances are running VMs. The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see region instances. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to See the Instance Console, Console Log, and Overview
Url.Abstract: How to See the Instance Console, Console Log, and Overview The instance console is the system log from the VM, and it is used for debugging and troubleshooting. You can view the full instance log or specify the number of lines of the log file to view.

Url.Title: How to See Info about Services, Compute Services, and Default Quotas
Url.Abstract: How to See Info about Services, Compute Services, and Default Quotas Concepts: Concepts The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see information about services, compute service and default quotas (limits). To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to See a List of Services
Url.Abstract: How to See a List of Services The Services window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a read-only list of registered services.

Url.Title: How to See a List of Compute Services
Url.Abstract: How to See a List of Compute Services The Compute Services window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a read-only list of registered compute services.

Url.Title: How to See a List of Default Quotas (Limits)
Url.Abstract: How to See a List of Default Quotas (Limits) The Default Quotas window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a read-only list of region quotas. The Administration Dashboard provides default limits, but you can modify those limits at the project level. See "How to Change a Project's Compute or Storage Limits" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Access Volumes
Url.Abstract: How to Access Volumes Concepts: Concepts The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission see volumes. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Create a Region Volume Type
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Region Volume Type To create a region volume type: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.

Url.Title: How to Delete a Volume Type
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Volume Type To delete one or more volume types: Click Region > Volumes to open the Volumes window.

Url.Title: How to Delete a Volume
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Volume Deleting a volume means the volume will no longer exist, the data will be lost, it cannot be attached to any VM, and no user can access it. Deleting a volume cannot be undone.

Url.Title: How to Access Images
Url.Abstract: How to Access Images Concepts: Concepts The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of images (that are not snapshots) and to work with those images. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Create an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Create an Image You can create and configure an image to upload to the image service used by the Administration Dashboard. The image must be available on an HTTP URL. Compressed image binaries, such as .zip, and .tar.gz, are supported.

Url.Title: How to Edit an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Edit an Image You cannot modify an image format. When you edit an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) image, you see additional fields allowing you to select a Kernel image (AKI) and a RAMdisk Image (ARI). An AMI image is not valid unless it is associated with an AKI and ARI.

Url.Title: How to Delete an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Delete an Image After you delete an image, you cannot create instances based on that (deleted) image. Also, if you delete an image that a topology template references, provisioning will fail.

Url.Title: How to Access Networks
Url.Abstract: How to Access Networks The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of networks and work with those networks. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Create an External Network
Url.Abstract: How to Create an External Network The Admin user or cloud administrators can create an external network on the Region tab. The cloud can only support one external network, so the network should be created as a shared network. As a shared network, it can be used by multiple projects, if needed.

Url.Title: How to Create a Private Network
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Private Network The Admin user and cloud administrators can create a private network on the Region tab.

Url.Title: Edit a Network (NEW)
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Network The Region > Networks window provides a convenient place for the Admin user and cloud administrators to see all the networks in all the regions, so administrators can decide which networks to edit.

Url.Title: Delete a Network (NEW)
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Network The Region > Networks window provides a convenient place for the Admin user and cloud administrators to see all the networks in all the regions, so administrators can decide which networks to delete.

Url.Title: How to Access Routers
Url.Abstract: How to Access Routers Concepts: Concepts The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of routers. and work with those routers. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Delete a Router
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Router The Region > Routers window provides a convenient place for the admin user and cloud administrators to see all the routers in all the regions, so administrators can decide which routers to delete.

Url.Title: How to Access Flavors and Flavor Extra Specs
Url.Abstract: How to Access Flavors and Flavor Extra Specs Concepts: Concepts The Region tab provides a convenient place for users who have permission to see a list of flavors and work with those flavors. To learn whether you have permission, see "Administration Dashboard Tasks by Role" on page 1.

Url.Title: How to Create a Flavor
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Flavor Only cloud architects can create flavors. Creating a flavor defines a new configuration used to create new VMs. Typically, the pre-defined flavors m1.tiny through m1.xlarge are valid.

Url.Title: How to Edit a Flavor
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Flavor To edit a region flavor: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region. Current Compute Region

Url.Title: How to Delete a Flavor
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Flavor Only a domain administrator within a region can delete flavors. When you delete a flavor, the flavor is no longer visible in the Administration Dashboard and cannot be used to create a new VM, to assign in resource pool services, or to specify in Infrastructure Design documents.

Url.Title: How to Create a Flavor Extra Spec
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Flavor Extra Spec You can create an extra spec key-value for a flavor. To create an extra spec for a flavor:

Url.Title: How to Edit a Flavor Extra Spec
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Flavor Extra Spec You can edit an extra spec value. If you make changes to the extra spec name, the Administration Dashboard creates a new extra specs key.

Url.Title: How to Delete a Flavor Extra Spec
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Flavor Extra Spec To delete a flavor extra specs key: Click Region > Flavors to open the Flavors window.

Url.Title: Project Tab Tasks
Url.Abstract: Project Tab Tasks Projects are groupings that allow designated users to view the same set of content. Projects protect topology templates, infrastructure designs, and realized resources (such as VMs, volumes, and others) from being visible to all users.

Url.Title: How to See a Project Overview
Url.Abstract: How to See a Project Overview To see a project overview: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: Running Topologies
Url.Abstract: Running Topologies Concepts: Concepts To see a list of running topologies: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: How to Launch a Topology
Url.Abstract: How to Launch a Topology You can launch the latest version of a topology design. To launch a topology design:

Url.Title: How to Delete or Terminate a Running Topology
Url.Abstract: How to Delete or Terminate a Running Topology When you delete a running topology, the Administration Dashboard stops the VM and other topology elements, and permanently removes them. This action cannot be undone.

Url.Title: Deployment Profiles
Url.Abstract: Deployment Profiles Concepts: Concepts To see a list of deployment profiles: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: How to Launch a Deployment Profile
Url.Abstract: How to Launch a Deployment Profile To launch a deployment profile: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: Resource Pools
Url.Abstract: Resource Pools Concepts: Concepts Resource pools are used to access various cloud providers. For multiple regions, one resource pool is required for each region.

Url.Title: How to Create a Resource Pool
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Resource Pool Resource pools help you locate compute and storage regions to use when you provision.

Url.Title: How to Edit a Resource Pool
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Resource Pool Use the Edit Resource Pool view to update resource pool definitions that will be used during topology provisioning. In common use cases, you can:

Url.Title: How to Add or Edit a Resource Pool Service
Url.Abstract: How to Add or Edit a Resource Pool Service Use the Edit Resource Pool Services view to add, edit, and delete services to and from a resource pool.

Url.Title: How to Delete a Resource Pool
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Resource Pool Make sure you really want to delete a resource pool. Deleted resource pools cannot be restored. You must recreate them.

Url.Title: Instances
Url.Abstract: Instances Concepts: Concepts Instances are all of the VMs running within a selected project. To view a list of instances:

Url.Title: How to Launch an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Launch an Instance When you set up an instance, carefully make your selections. After the instance is launched, the only editable property is its Name.

Url.Title: How to Create an Instance Snapshot
Url.Abstract: How to Create an Instance Snapshot After you set up, install, and configure an instance, you can create a snapshot to preserve the disk state of the running instance. At a later time, you can use the snapshot to start up another VM.

Url.Title: How to Edit an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Edit an Instance To edit a project instance: On the Project tab, select a Current Project. Current Project

Url.Title: How to Associate a Floating IP to an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Associate a Floating IP to an Instance You can associate a Floating IP address to an instance that needs to be visible outside the cloud.

Url.Title: How to Disassociate a Floating IP from an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Disassociate a Floating IP from an Instance To disassociate a floating IP from an instance: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: How to Pause or Resume an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Pause or Resume an Instance Pausing an instance stores the content of the VM in memory (RAM). This keeps the instance running, but in a frozen state.

Url.Title: How to Hard Reboot an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Hard Reboot an Instance Rebooting an instance is similar to cycling power on a physical server—the operating system is restarted from scratch. Rebooting temporarily makes the VM and all the services it hosts unavailable. In a common use case, your installation requires a reboot because you installed new software.

Url.Title: How to Suspend or Resume an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Suspend or Resume an Instance Suspending an instance frees up memory and vCPUs. Suspension could be compared to hibernation mode.

Url.Title: How to Force Delete an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Force Delete an Instance Use the Force Delete option to delete an instance when it appears to be in an unresponsive state. Any user has the option to Force Delete, which immediately and completely deletes the instance from the project.

Url.Title: Volumes
Url.Abstract: Volumes Concepts: Concepts Volumes are the disk storage volumes that have been created in the project. Volumes are persistent—you can create data in these volumes and attach them to various VMs (instances) over time, as needed.

Url.Title: How to Create a Volume
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Volume You can create a volume by entering the size, or you can use a volume snapshot as a source. After you create a volume, you can attach it to a VM and place content in it.

Url.Title: How to Create a Volume from an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Volume from an Image To create a volume from an image: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: How to Attach or Detach Volumes to an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Attach or Detach Volumes to an Instance Volumes are disk storage volumes that have been created in a project and can be attached to an instance. A volume can only be attached to a single VM at a time, and that VM has sole use of that volume.

Url.Title: How to Delete a Volume
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Volume Deleting a volume means the volume will no longer exist, the data will be lost, it cannot be attached to any VM, and no user can access it.

Url.Title: Images and Snapshots
Url.Abstract: Images and Snapshots Concepts: Concepts When you launch a VM, the launch is based on an image. This Images view lists only the launchable images that can be used to create new VMs:

Url.Title: How to Create an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Create an Image You can create and configure an image to upload to the Image Service. The image must be available on an HTTP URL. Compressed image binaries, such as .zip, and .tar.gz, are supported.

Url.Title: How to Launch an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Launch an Image You can only launch images that are formatted as AMI, RAW, and QCOW2. Launching an image provisions it to the cloud.

Url.Title: How to Delete an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Delete an Image Images are protected from deletion by rules. If you are not allowed to delete an image, you do not see Delete Image.

Url.Title: How to Edit an Instance Snapshot
Url.Abstract: How to Edit an Instance Snapshot To edit an instance snapshot: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: How to Launch an Instance Snapshot
Url.Abstract: How to Launch an Instance Snapshot To launch an instance snapshot: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: How to Delete an Instance Snapshot
Url.Abstract: How to Delete an Instance Snapshot To delete one instance snapshots: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: How to Delete a Volume Snapshot
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Volume Snapshot Deleting a volume snapshot cannot be undone. To delete one or more volume snapshots:

Url.Title: Networks
Url.Abstract: Networks Concepts: Concepts From this view, you can create, edit, and delete project networks. You can also add subnets using this view.

Url.Title: Create a Network
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Network You can create a network that is assigned to your current project. You cannot create an external network on the Project tab. You must have access to the Region tab to create a shared or external network. See "How to Create an External Network" on page 1.

Url.Title: Edit a Network
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Network You can edit a network that is assigned to a project. In a common use case, you need to edit when the Admin State should be changed, such as for maintenance or testing efforts.

Url.Title: Delete a Network
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Network You can delete a network that is assigned to a project. In a common use case, you want to delete a network that you decide is no longer required in the project.

Url.Title: Add a Subnet
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Subnet You can create a subnet on a network. Subnets allow you to divide a network into addressable segments.

Url.Title: Edit a Subnet
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Subnet The Region > Networks window provides a convenient place for the admin user and cloud administrators to see all the subnets in all the regions, so administrators can decide which subnets to edit.

Url.Title: How to Delete a Subnet
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Subnet To delete a subnet: On the Project tab, select a Current Project. Current Project

Url.Title: Routers
Url.Abstract: Routers A router is a logical entity for forwarding packets across internal subnets and NATting them on external networks through an appropriate external gateway.

Url.Title: Create a Router
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Router You can create a router to interconnect subnets and forward traffic within the subnets. A router also enables you to NAT internal traffic to external networks.

Url.Title: Configure a Router
Url.Abstract: How to Configure a Router To configure a router in a network topology: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: Add an Interface
Url.Abstract: How to Add an Internal Interface to a Router To add an internal interface to a project router: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: Add a Gateway Interface
Url.Abstract: How to Add an External Interface to a Router To add an external interface to a router: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: Delete a Router
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Router To delete one or more project routers: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: Network Topology
Url.Abstract: Network Topology Concepts: Concepts You can view private and public networks that are connected by a router.

Url.Title: Create a Network
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Network Topology A network is an isolated, virtual, layer-2, broadcast domain that is typically reserved for the tenant who created it, unless the network is configured to be shared. Tenants can create multiple networks until they reach the thresholds specified by per-tenant.

Url.Title: Launch an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Launch an Instance of Network Topology To launch an instance of a network topology: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: Security Groups and Rules
Url.Abstract: Security Groups and Rules Concepts: Concepts Security groups are one way to provide a measure of network isolation between different VMs because they limit the ports into which network traffic can enter the group. Within a security group, you can add, edit, and delete rules to specify communications to other ports.

Url.Title: How to Create or Delete a Security Group
Url.Abstract: How to Create or Delete a Security Group Security groups are one way to provide a measure of network isolation between different VMs because they limit the ports into which network traffic can enter the group. Within a security group, you can add, edit, and delete rules to specify communications to other ports.

Url.Title: How to Configure a Default Security Group
Url.Abstract: How to Configure a Default Security Group To configure a default security group: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: How to Add or Delete a Security Group Rule
Url.Abstract: How to Add or Delete a Security Group Rule Within a security group, you can add, edit, and delete rules to specify communications to other ports.

Url.Title: How to Import, Create, or Delete a Keypair
Url.Abstract: How to Import, Create, or Delete a Keypair If you need a keypair, you must create or import the keypair for yourself. No other user can create or import a keypair for you.

Url.Title: Floating IPs
Url.Abstract: Floating IPs Tasks: Tasks "How to Allocate a Floating IP" on page 1 "How to Associate and Disassociate Floating IPs" on page 1

Url.Title: How to Allocate a Floating IP
Url.Abstract: How to Allocate a Floating IP You can allocate additional floating IP addresses to a project. This process does not assign the address to a particular instance in the project.

Url.Title: How to Associate and Disassociate Floating IPs
Url.Abstract: How to Associate and Disassociate Floating IPs You can associate and disassociate floating IPs. You can assign an address to a particular VM instance.

Url.Title: How to Release a Floating IP
Url.Abstract: How to Release a Floating IP A floating IP address that is associated with a particular project can be released back to the pool, which makes it available for other projects.

Url.Title: How to Access API Endpoints
Url.Abstract: How to Access API Endpoints To access API endpoints: On the Project tab, select a Current Project. Current Project

Url.Title: How to Access Your Authentication Token
Url.Abstract: How to Access Your Authentication Token The Administration Dashboard manages your authentication token. The Administration Dashboard retrieves your token from the Keystone service when you successfully log in to the dashboard.

Url.Title: Updates and Extensions
Url.Abstract: Updates and Extensions Concepts: Concepts The Updates and Extensions window provides a convenient place for users who have permission to access the HP Cloud OS Distribution Network. Use the Updates and Extensions window to access catalog updates and content. Updates include software versions and security patches. Content includes material such as images and topology templates.

Url.Title: How to Configure an Updates and Extensions Account
Url.Abstract: How to Configure an Updates and Extensions Account If you want to use CODN, you must configure the Administration Dashboard to access it. If you do not have access, the Administration Dashboard displays a warning when you open the Updates and Extensions window.

Url.Title: How to Download an Update or Extension
Url.Abstract: How to Download an Update or Extension Download an update to copy it from the catalog to your local system where you can use it. If an update is not available for download, you do not see Download. For example, you cannot download an update that was previously downloaded and still exists in cache.

Url.Title: How to Publish an Update or Extension
Url.Abstract: How to Publish an Update or Extension You can publish an update after you download it. If you have not yet downloaded the update, you do not see Publish.

Url.Title: Administration Dashboard Settings
Url.Abstract: Administration Dashboard Settings Concepts: Concepts All users see the Settings link on every Administration Dashboard window. The link allows you to change your personal settings and access online help.

Url.Title: How to Change User Settings
Url.Abstract: How to Change User Settings To change Administration Dashboard display settings: Administration Dashboard

Url.Title: How to Change Your Password
Url.Abstract: How to Change Your Password To change your Administration Dashboard password: Administration Dashboard

Url.Title: About the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard
Url.Abstract: About the HP Cloud OS Administration Dashboard To view version information about the Administration Dashboard:

Url.Title: Administration Dashboard Overview
Url.Abstract: Administration Dashboard Overview Administration Dashboard This would be a good place for information or graphics about flow, or other high-level material.

Url.Title: Additional Infrastructure Tasks for Project Administrators
Url.Abstract: Additional Infrastructure Tasks for Project Administrators Delete this text and replace it with your own content.

Url.Title: Additional Infrastructure Tasks for Project Users
Url.Abstract: Additional Infrastructure Tasks for Project Users Delete this text and replace it with your own content.

Url.Title: Additional Provisioning Tasks for Project Users
Url.Abstract: Additional Provisioning Tasks for Project Users Delete this text and replace it with your own content.

Url.Title: Edit a Project Image
Url.Abstract: Edit a Project Image How to Edit an Image You cannot modify an image format. When you edit an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) image, you see additional fields allowing you to select a Kernel image (AKI) and a RAMdisk Image (ARI). An AMI image is not valid unless it is associated with an AKI and ARI.

Url.Title: How to Create an External Router
Url.Abstract: How to Create an External Router To create an external router: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: Getting Started for Project Users
Url.Abstract: Getting Started for Project Users This intro material will include: links or text for concepts about the project user role

Url.Title: How to Determine Your Public IP Address Range
Url.Abstract: How to Determine Your Public IP Address Range To do

Url.Title: How to View Resource Usage across All Tenants
Url.Abstract: How to View Resource Usage across All Tenants To Do

Url.Title: Domains
Url.Abstract: Domains Conceptual material: Tasks: Tasks

Url.Title: Image Repositories
Url.Abstract: Image Repositories Cloud administrators can create image repositories on the Cloud > Images window and make the images public. Users can access those images on Project Infrastructure > Images and use them to launch a VM.

Url.Title: How to Create an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Create an Image Cloud administrators can create images on the Domain > Images window. The image must be available on an HTTP URL. Compressed image binaries, such as .zip, and .tar.gz, are supported.

Url.Title: How to Delete an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Delete an Image After you delete an image, you cannot create instances based on that (deleted) image. Also, if you delete an image that a topology document references, the infrastructure design document will fail during an attempt to provision.

Url.Title: How to Edit an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Edit an Image You cannot modify an image format. When you edit an Amazon Machine Image (AMI) image, you see additional fields allowing you to select a Kernel image (AKI) and a RAMdisk Image (ARI). An AMI image is not valid unless it is associated with an AKI and ARI.

Url.Title: How to Launch an Image
Url.Abstract: How to Launch an Image The cloud admin can launch images on the Cloud > Images window. The Cloud OS uploads the image to your image service.

Url.Title: Projects
Url.Abstract: Projects There is only one set of projects. Under Cloud Projects, all projects are visible. Under Domain Projects, only the projects visible to that domain are listed.

Url.Title: How to Create a Project
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Project When you create a project, you need only one required entry - Name. You can keep default settings for integrations and limits, and add users later.

Url.Title: How to Delete or Restore a Project
Url.Abstract: How to Delete or Restore a Project Cloud administrators can delete or restore projects on the Domain > Projects window. You cannot delete the AdminProject.

Url.Title: How to Edit a Project
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Project Cloud administrators can update project details and limits on the Domain > Project window.

Url.Title: How to Add or Remove a Project User
Url.Abstract: How to Add or Remove a Project User Cloud administrators can add and remove project members on the Cloud window.

Url.Title: Roles
Url.Abstract: Roles Use roles to give a user privileges to access project resources. Different roles assign different privileges.

Url.Title: How to Create a Role
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Role Cloud administrators can create a new role on the Domain tab. To create a role: Click Domain > Roles to open the Roles view.

Url.Title: How to Delete, Disable, or Enable a Role
Url.Abstract: How to Delete, Disable, or Enable a Role Cloud administrators can delete a role. When you delete a role, it is removed throughout the Administration Dashboard.

Url.Title: How to Edit a Role
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a Role Cloud administrators can edit a role to change the name that is associated with the role. The role maintains the privileges that were previously assigned to it, but with a different name. In a common use case, you edit a domain role name to be more appropriate to your company's titles.

Url.Title: Domain Services
Url.Abstract: Domain Services Keystone is the security context and the defining service for a cloud. All services connected to a single Keystone service belong in one cloud. Glance, in the recommend configuration, is also a cloud service because the images it provides are available to VMs in all regions.

Url.Title: Project Users
Url.Abstract: Project Users Conceptual material. Users include both people and services, such as Nova. When you create a user, you create the user, and add that user to a project and a project role.

Url.Title: How to Create a User
Url.Abstract: How to Create a User Cloud administrators can create a user on the Domain tab. To create a user: Click Domain > Users to open the Users window.

Url.Title: How to Delete, Disable, or Enable a User
Url.Abstract: How to Delete, Disable, or Enable a User Cloud administrators can delete, disable, and enable users. Note: You cannot delete, disable, or enable the following users: Admin, Arch, and control users such as Trash or Nova. Delete, Disable, and Enable do not display for those users.

Url.Title: How to Add or Remove a Role from a User
Url.Abstract: How to Add or Remove a Role from a User You must be logged in to the Administration Dashboard as a cloud administrator.

Url.Title: How to Edit a User
Url.Abstract: How to Edit a User Cloud administrators can edit users. Note: You cannot edit control users such as Trash or Nova. Edit does not display for users that cannot be edited.

Url.Title: Getting Started for Project Users
Url.Abstract: Getting Started for Project Users Conceptual material about what all users should know. Work through the tasks below and then go to your user section.

Url.Title: How to Create a Dynamic Load Balancer
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Dynamic Load Balancer You can create a dynamic load balancer that provisions a load balancer instance when you provision a topology. When you use this load balancer method, you create a load balancer instance for each topology.

Url.Title: Access and Security
Url.Abstract: Access and Security rework the following material You can view and manage the following project access and security elements:

Url.Title: How to Terminate an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Terminate an Instance When you terminate an instance, the VM is shut down and the resources associated with it are released. It is not possible to start the VM after it is terminated because it no longer exists. Termination is scheduled because it takes some time to free all the resources.

Url.Title: Create a Router
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Router in a Network Topology To create a router in a network topology: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: View a Network Topology
Url.Abstract: How to See a Network Topology In the Administration Dashboard, you can view private and public networks that are connected by a router.

Url.Title: Object Storage
Url.Abstract: Object Storage During cloud creation, the admin user can choose to install the OpenStack Swift service. Hi Tapan - Does this happen in Cosmos or Skyline? The service is a highly available, distributed, consistent object/blob store, which is useful as persistent storage. If the admin user installs Swift, you see the Object Storage on the Project tab.

Url.Title: How to Create a Container
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Container To create a conatiner: On the Project tab, select a Current Project . Current Project

Url.Title: How to Delete a Container
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Container To delete a container: On the Project tab, select a Current Project . Current Project

Url.Title: How to Copy a Container Object
Url.Abstract: How to Copy a Container Object To copy a container object: On the Project tab, select a Current Project .

Url.Title: How to Delete a Container Object
Url.Abstract: How to Delete a Container Object To delete a container object: On the Project tab, select a Current Project .

Url.Title: How to Download a Container Object
Url.Abstract: How to Download a Container Object Hi Tapan - Let's explain what this does. What is the use case? To download a container object:

Url.Title: How to Upload a Container Object
Url.Abstract: How to Upload a Container Object Tapan - Let's explain what this does. What is the use case? To upload a container object:

Url.Title: View Router Details
Url.Abstract: How to View Router Details Add to UI Description material. To view general information about a project router:

Url.Title: Scripts
Url.Abstract: Scripts Tell what scripts are. To see a list of scripts: On the Project tab, select aCurrent Project . Current Project

Url.Title: Project Snapshots
Url.Abstract: Project Snapshots Snapshots preserve the disk state of running instances and volumes. You can view snapshots that were created in the Instances and Volumes sections of the Region tab.

Url.Title: How to Create a Volume Snapshot
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Volume Snapshot To create a project volume snapshot: On the Project tab, select a Current Project.

Url.Title: How to Create a Volume from a Snapshot
Url.Abstract: How to Create a Volume from a Snapshot You can use a volume snapshot to create a new volume. To create a volume from a project snapshot:

Url.Title: Region Flavor Extra Specs
Url.Abstract: Region Flavor Extra Specs You can create an extra spec key-value for a flavor. To view extra spec key-values for a flavor:

Url.Title: How to Edit an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Edit an Instance To edit a region instance: On the Region tab, select a Current Compute Region.

Url.Title: How to Launch an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Launch an Instance You can launch an instance into a project, if you are a member of that project. Even a cloud administrator must be a member of a project to launch an instance into that project.

Url.Title: How to Migrate an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Migrate an Instance Use migrate to migrate a running instance from one OpenStack compute server to another OpenStack compute server.

Url.Title: How to Pause or Resume an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Pause or Resume an Instance When you pause an instance, the Administration Dashboard stores the content of the VM in memory (RAM). This keeps the instance running, but in a frozen state.

Url.Title: How to Hard Reboot an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Hard Reboot an Instance Rebooting an instance is similar to cycling power on a physical server—the operating system is restarted from scratch. Rebooting temporarily makes the VM and all the services it hosts unavailable. In a common use case, you install new software on the VM, and the installation requires a reboot.

Url.Title: How to Soft Reboot an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Soft Reboot an Instance This is new. We need to explain it. How is it different from a hard reboot?

Url.Title: How to Create an Instance Snapshot
Url.Abstract: How to Create an Instance Snapshot After you set up, install, and configure an instance, you can create a snapshot to preserve the disk state of the running instance. At a later time, you can use the snapshot to start up another VM.

Url.Title: How to Suspend, Resume, or Terminate an Instance
Url.Abstract: How to Suspend, Resume, or Terminate an Instance When you suspend a region instance, you free up its memory and vCPUs. Suspension could be compared to hibernation mode.

Url.Title: Additional Tasks for All Users
Url.Abstract: Additional Tasks for All Users Delete this text and replace it with your own content.

Url.Title: How to Define a Set of Topology Template Documents
Url.Abstract: How to Define a Set of Topology Template Documents Delete this text and replace it with your own content.

Url.Title: Topology Designs
Url.Abstract: Topology Designs
